summary.title: Assignment2
summary.description:
A web-based application designed to register dogs in order to get their identification
tags, as well as the management and traceability of dogs. Owners can register their dogs, and receive or renew their
unique tags delivered by the Council. Dogs can be declared lost or found, and owners can terminate a registration
before its expiration date.

data.name: Dog Owner
data.description: A person living in the jurisdiction of the Council who owns one or more dogs.

threats.title: Denial of lost dog report
threats.description: Dog owner might later deny having made the lost dog report.
threats.mitigation:
* Send a confirmation email to the email address upon report process completion
* Maintain robust and secure logs of all transactions on the app
* Provide confirmation page when the report process has been completed

threats.title: Stolen credentials
threats.description: Credentials of the dog owner (e.g., email address and dog's name) can be stolen or guessed.
threats.mitigation:
* Verify email address during report process. When a report is submitted, a verification link or code should be sent to the email address provided. which the user must click or enter on the website to confirm the report
* Require additional information to identify the dog owner, such as the dog tag ID or unique registration number
* Flag multiple lost dog reports coming from the same IP address

threats.title: Insecure Connection
threats.description: Data can be tampered by an adversary in the middle where the users email or dog name, id number or breed can be modified, for example.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security for the communication.

threats.title: Unauthorised modification of dog data
threats.description: An attacker might gain unauthorised access and alter the information of the dog (e.g., name, lost status, owner, dog tag ID).
threats.mitigation:
* Utilise hashing and checksum mechanisms to detect and prevent unauthorised changes to data
* Implement role based access controls to restrict database write permissions to authorised personnel only
* Regular audits and integrity checks on the database to identify any unauthorised changes

threats.title: Dog datastore unwanted access
threats.description: Sensitive information might be exposed to unauthorised individuals.
threats.mitigation:
* Datastore credentials are securely stored on password vaults with limited set of users having access (apply least privilege principle).
* Datastore credentials are injected into connecting software from secured variables or files (apply least privilege principle).

threats.title: Disruption of service
threats.description: Could be flooded with malicious requests or exploit vulnerabilities to disrupt the availability of the data.
threats.mitigation: * Employ rate limiting and traffic monitoring

threats.title: New STRIDE threat
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat
threats.mitigation: Provide remediation for this threat or a reason if status is N/A

data.name:
Manufacture and
 send new tag
data.description: Some third party creates a tag with the specified number on it and sends it to the Dog owner's postal address

threats.title: Fraudulent reporting
threats.description: A user could obtain another user's email address, dog ID, and dog name, and fraudulently terminate the dog's registration.
threats.mitigation:
* Require authentication for registration termination with unique short-lived session token.
* Use HTTP-only and secure cookies.

threats.title: Deny terminating registration
threats.description: A user could claim that somebody else impersonated them and terminated the dog's registration
threats.mitigation:
* Trace (log) session id, timestamp, originating IP and user id in log.
* Validate hashed checksum with end-user's public key.
* Send confirmation email (with email log).

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: Multiple requests coming from the same IP, or multiple requests to terminate the same dog registration.
threats.mitigation: * Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.

data.name:
Report Lost 
Dog
data.description: Action to report a lost dog

threats.title: Fraudulent reporting
threats.description: Attackers may impersonate the dog owner if they know their email address and the dog's name. This can lead to false reports and the attacker also gains the dogs most recent tag ID.

threats.title: False information insertion
threats.description: Attackers could gain unauthorised access and insert false information.
threats.mitigation:
* Apply security patches
* Secure the process logic
* Implement strong input validation

threats.title: Information leakage during report
threats.description: Sensitive information such as the dog owner's email and the dog's name could be leaked.
threats.mitigation:
* Ensure that sensitive information is accessible only to authorised users and processes
* Encrypt data at rest and in use within the process to prevent unauthorised disclosure
* Prevent unauthorised execution or access to the process that could expose sensitive information

threats.title: Exploitation of privilege escalation
threats.description: Attackers could exploit vulnerabilities in the process to gain unauthorised access to elevated privileges, potentially allowing them to alter or delete reports or access other restricted functions.
threats.mitigation:
* Restrict the user of privileged accounts and enforce the principle of least privilege
* Regularly scan for and patch vulnerabilities that could be exploited for privilege escalation

threats.title: Overload request
threats.description: Attackers could overload the process by sending a large number of fake or malicious requests, leading to a denial of service that prevents legitimate users from reporting lost dogs.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to prevent DoS attacks
* Ensure that backups are available to restore normal operations quickly
* Monitor for unusual spikes in traffic and automatically block suspicious activity

threats.title: Malformed data
threats.description: Attackers could pass through specially crafted malformed data to crash the system.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement strong input validation and handle unexpected data types
* Ensure that a backup mechanism is in place to quickly restore service 
* Monitor data submissions for signs of DoS attempts in malformed data

threats.title: Fake emails
threats.description: Attackers could send fake emails to the dog owners, leading to confusion and potential security breaches.
threats.mitigation:
* Include specific information in the email that only the council would know (e.g., registration number)
* Use domain-based email authentication protocols like SPF, DKIM, and DMARC

threats.title: Tampering with email template
threats.description: Attackers could gain unauthorised access and change the email template or insert malicious links into the content.
threats.mitigation:
* Digitally sign emails to ensure the integrity of the content
* Use secure templates that cannot be easily modified by unauthorised users or processes

threats.title: Denial of email service
threats.description: Attackers send a high volume of data or specially crafted requests to cause it to fail.
threats.mitigation:
* Control the rate of requests and filter and block suspicious or excessive traffic
* Implement failover mechanisms to maintain service availability
* Implement strict validation of all incoming data 
* Distribute the load of requests across multiple servers or instances to balance load
* Slow down or limit the processing of requests during high traffic periods

threats.title: Email information leakage
threats.description: Sensitive information stored in plaintext or fails to protect the email content before sending it
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt sensitive information
* Securely manage logs

threats.title: Denial of receipt
threats.description: Dog owners might deny having received an email.
threats.mitigation:
* Use delivery and read receipts to track when emails are delivered and opened by the recipient
* Store confirmation of receipt in the system logs

data.name: Dog Tag ID
data.description: Returns the dog tag ID from the dog name.

threats.title: Incorrect data return
threats.description: Attackers could intercept and alter the dog tag ID during transmission, passing through incorrect data and causing confusion or misuse of the system.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data in transit
* Implement data integrity checks (e.g., cryptographic hashes or HMAC)

threats.title: Interception of dog tag ID data
threats.description: Attackers could intercept the dog tag ID during transmission.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data during transmission
* Secure and isolate the network paths used to transmit sensitive data
* Ensure that access to the dog tag ID data is restricted to authorised processes and entities only

data.name: Dog Status
data.description: Passes the new "lost" dog status.

threats.title: Tampering with dog status data
threats.description: Attackers could intercept and alter the dog status data as it is being transmitted, which could lead to incorrect data being stored, causing confusion or misuse of the system.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data in transit
* Implement data integrity checks (e.g., cryptographic hashes or HMAC) to verify that the data has not been altered during transmission
* Log and monitor all data flows to detect and respond to any unauthorised modifications

threats.title: Interception of dog status data
threats.description: Information about the dog's status could be intercepted as it is transmitted to the datastore.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data during transmission
* Secure and isolate the network paths used to transmit sensitive data
* Ensure that access to the dog status data is restricted to authorised processes and entities only

data.name:
Confirmation
Email
data.description: An email indicating that the dog has been declared lost, with the dog tag ID included in the email.

threats.title: Altering confirmation email data
threats.description: Attackers could intercept and alter the confirmation email in transit, causing confusion or unintended actions from the dog owner.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the email content in transit
* Implement digital signatures (e.g., DKIM) for emails
* Monitor and log email transmissions

threats.title: Interception of confirmation email
threats.description: Attackers could intercept the confirmation email and gain sensitive information such as the dog tag ID and the dog owner's email address.
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt the email content using TLS
* Secure and isolate the network paths used to transmit the confirmation email
* Implement email authentication protocols (e.g., SPF, DKIM, DMARC)

threats.title: Tampering with email data
threats.description: Attackers could intercept and alter the content of the email before it is sent to the email provider, leading to false information being sent to the dog owner.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data in transit
* Implement data integrity checks (e.g., HMAC) to ensure that the data sent has not been altered

threats.title: Data interception on email transmission
threats.description: Sensitive information being transmitted to the email provider could be intercepted by an attacker, revealing the dog owner's email, dog tag ID, and dog's status.
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt the data in transit using TLS
* Secure and isolate the network paths used to transmit sensitive data
* Ensure that access to the data flow is restricted to authorised processes and users only

data.name:
Confirmation
Webpage
data.description:
Webpage showing:
  * dog's status has been updated to lost
  * dog ID

threats.title: False information display
threats.description: Attackers alter the dog tag ID displayed to the user, causing confusion to the user.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to secure the data flow
* Implement strong output encoding

threats.title: Data interception on confirmation page
threats.description: Attackers could intercept the data and gain access to the dog tag ID and potentially other sensitive information.
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt the data in transit using TLS
* Ensure that only authorised users can access the webpage
* Isolate and secure the network paths used to transmit sensitive information to the user

data.name: Report Data
data.description:
This data contains:
  * email address used to register the dog
  * dog's name

threats.title: Tampering with reported data
threats.description: Attackers could intercept and alter the data, leading to false information being recorded.
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt data in transit using TLS
* Implement data integrity checks (e.g., HMAC) to ensure that the data has not been altered during transmission
* Log and monitor all data transmissions to detect and respond to any tampering attempts

threats.title: Data interception on report data
threats.description: Sensitive information, such as the dog owner's email address and the dog's name could be intercepted during transmission
threats.mitigation:
* Encrypt data during transmission
* Isolate the communication channels used for transmitting sensitive data
* Implement secure communication channels

threats.title: Unauthorised modification of dog data
threats.description: An attacker might alter the information of the dog (e.g., name, lost status, owner, dog tag ID).
threats.mitigation:
* Utilise hashing and checksum mechanisms to detect and prevent unauthorised changes to data
* Implement role based access controls to restrict database write permissions to authorised personnel only
* Regular audits and integrity checks on the database to identify any unauthorised changes

threats.title: Dog datastore unwanted access
threats.description: Sensitive information might be exposed to unauthorised individuals from stolen credentials.
threats.mitigation:
* Datastore credentials are securely stored on password vaults with limited set of users having access (apply least privilege principle).
* Datastore credentials are injected into connecting software from secured variables or files (apply least privilege principle).

threats.title: Overloading with requests
threats.description: Attackers could overwhelm the datastore by sending an excessive number of requests, causing it to slow down or crash.
threats.mitigation:
* Employ rate limiting and traffic monitoring
* Ensure redundancy and failover mechanisms are in place so that backup systems can take over

threats.title: Disputed data changes
threats.description: An attacker or insider could dispute or deny making changes to records within the datastore, leading to challenges in auditing and accountability.
threats.mitigation:
* Maintain detailed, tamper-evident logs of all actions performed on the datastore, including timestamps, user IDs, and specific changes
* Use cryptographic signatures on logs
* Restrict access to the datastore and its logs, allowing only authorised personnel to make changes

threats.title: Storing malformed data
threats.description: Attackers could send malformed data to the datastore, causing it to crash, consume excessive resources, or corrupt the stored data.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement input validation and sanitisation to ensure that all data sent is properly formatted
* Use data integrity checks and robust error handling within the datastore

diagrams.description: Diagram for declaring a lost dog

threats.title: Fradulent reporting
threats.description: A user could obtain another user's email address, dog ID, and dog name, and fraudulently terminate the dog's registration.
threats.mitigation:
* Require authentication for registration termination with unique short-lived session token.
* Use HTTP-only and secure cookies.

threats.title: Deny terminating registration
threats.description: A user could claim that somebody else impersonated them and terminated the dog's registration
threats.mitigation:
* Trace (log) session id, timestamp, originating IP and user id in log.
* Validate hashed checksum with end-user's public key.
* Send confirmation email (with email log).

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: Multiple requests coming from the same IP, or multiple requests to terminate the same dog registration.
threats.mitigation: * Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.

threats.title: Adversary in the middle change dog ID
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the request to terminate a dogs registration and modify its content.
threats.mitigation:
* Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id.
* Sign (hash) content with user's private key.

threats.title: Unregistered user tries to terminate dogs registration
threats.description: An unregistered user sends a request to terminate a dogs registration
threats.mitigation:
* Use unique session id to ensure user is currently logged in the system.
* Apply least privilege principle, i.e. only registered user can access the action.

threats.description: Data can be tampered by an adversary in the middle where the dogs breed can be modified, for example.
